div.head: Report:
div.p: Pressure-induced metallization and molecular dissociation of oxygen, 0,, with molecular magnetism have attracted special interest because of novel electronic and magnetic prop&es of the h&h-pressure phases. Determination of the structural prop&es of these phases is in&pensable for understanding the electro-magnetic properties, Recently, by using a high-brilliance beam of ESRF, we have observed a new structural transition from the a to 5 phase at 96 GPa co~espond~g to metallization[l]. Further studies on high-pressure phases of solid oxygen were carried out as follow.

div.head: l.Research'for molecular dissociation
div.p: Powder X-ray diffraction expeiment to 182 GPa was accomplished for solid oxygen by an angle-dispersive method with h=O.4223& Obtained patterns are showned in Fig. 1. The transition to the c phase at 96 GPa reappeared. Figure 2 shows the pressure dependence of the d-values of the difiaction peaks. The present data well agree with previous ones[ 11. These results above 96 GPa indicate none of sign for a structural transition. To determine and refine the structure of the <phase, the lines from a metal gasket ought to be removed from the patterns. Further experiments at higher pressure are needed for observation of molecular dissociation.

div.head: 2.Reitveld refinement of the E phase
div.p: For the E phase, the space group of C2/m has been proposed but the atomic positional parameter are not determined. The present Reitveld refinement has suggested a possible arrangement of oxygen molecules in the unit cell; the molecular axis of 0, is orientated to c-axis. But strong preferred-orientation of the sample powder made further refinement difficult.

div.head: 3.Single-crystal analysis of the E phase
div.p: Single crystals of the E phase was grown under a condition 20 GPa and 650 K in a DAC for the crystal structure analysis. Obtained oscillation photograph showed that the single crystal analysis is feasible. We could determined the c-axis direction of the crystal. Polarization property of i&ared spectra of this crystal supported our suggestion of the molecular arrangement.
